message_1: A sample of radioactive material with an initial activity of 80 Ci has a half-life of 10 days. What will be the activity of the sample after 30 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

where Activity_final is the activity of the sample after the given time, Activity_initial is the initial activity of the sample, time_elapsed is the time that has passed, and half_life is the half-life of the radioactive material.

In this case, we have:

Activity_initial = 80 Ci
half_life = 10 days
time_elapsed = 30 days

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

Activity_final = 80 Ci * (1/2)^(30 days / 10 days)

Activity_final = 80 Ci * (1/2)^3

Activity_final = 80 Ci * (1/8)

Activity_final = 10 Ci

So, the activity of the sample after 30 days will be 10 Ci.
